works.title: Vintage Catcher Photograph
works.narrative: This photograph captures an early baseball catcher in full gear, representing the evolution of protective equipment in the late 19th century.
works.description: A rare vintage photograph showing detailed catcher's equipment from the 1890s era.
works.provenance: Private collection, acquired from estate sale

works.title: Syracuse Stars Team Composite
works.narrative: Robert Higgins, pitcher, was one of the last black players to play professional baseball on an integrated team until Jackie Robinson, almost sixty years later. Manager Simmons ordered the Syracuse Stars to report at eleven o'clock on a Sunday morning to the studio operated by P. S. Ryder, who was also a club shareholder, to have a team portrait made, but two of Higgins's teammates refused to be photographed with him. Ryder produced this composite in lieu of a team photograph.
works.description: Cabinet card composite photograph of the Syracuse Stars baseball team, created when two players refused to be photographed with Robert Higgins, the team's Black pitcher.
works.provenance: Syracuse Historical Society archives

works.title: Wheeling Team Photograph
works.narrative: A team photograph from the Wheeling baseball club, representing the integrated nature of some early professional teams before the color line was firmly established.
works.description: Team photograph showing integrated baseball team from Wheeling.
works.provenance: West Virginia Historical Society

works.title: Weldy Walker Discrimination Appeal
works.narrative: Weldy Walker's formal appeal against racial discrimination in professional baseball, one of the earliest documented challenges to the emerging color line.
works.description: Historical document showing Weldy Walker's written appeal against discrimination.
works.provenance: National Archives, acquired through historical document dealer

works.title: Street Children Running
works.narrative: Children playing baseball in urban streets, representing the grassroots nature of the game across all communities during the segregation era.
works.description: Street photography showing children at play, illustrating baseball's universal appeal.
works.provenance: Urban photography collection

works.title: Negro League Clubhouse Scene
works.narrative: A candid photograph capturing players from an unidentified Negro League team in their clubhouse, gathered around a pool table during leisure time. The informal setting provides rare documentation of the social culture within these baseball organizations.
works.description: Candid clubhouse photograph showing Negro League players during leisure time.
works.provenance: Private collection, acquired from estate of former Negro League player, c. 1980s

works.title: Negro League Player in Pool Hall
works.narrative: This atmospheric photograph shows a Negro League player lining up a shot in what appears to be a Harlem pool hall. The setting exemplifies the leisure venues where black baseball stars cultivated their public personas and connected with their communities.
works.description: Atmospheric photograph of Negro League player in Harlem pool hall setting.
works.provenance: Acquired from Harlem photography studio archive, 1990s

works.title: New York Negro League Player
works.narrative: The New York Black Yankees played at Yankee Stadium and had uniforms that closely mimicked those of the white club, providing this image with poignancy as Paige is so close to the Major Leagues, superficially, and yet so far away.
works.description: Portrait of New York Black Yankees player, showing the visual proximity yet social distance from Major League Baseball.
works.provenance: LIFE Picture Collection

works.title: Western Union Telegram - Branch Rickey
works.narrative: It would be difficult to overstate the historical significance of these two telegrams, as they are the only surviving objects related directly to the events of August 1945. The first marks the very moment contact with Robinson had been made by the Dodgers organization and arranges for the historic meeting between Robinson and Rickey.
works.description: Western Union telegram from Branch Rickey to Clyde Sukeforth, establishing first contact with Jackie Robinson.
works.provenance: Branch Rickey estate, by descent to his grandson

works.title: Jackie Robinson Contract Signing
works.narrative: This photograph, taken during a contract signing, exemplifies Branch Rickey's deliberate use of images and powerful symbolism in shaping the narrative of Jackie Robinson's integration into Major League Baseball. For this photo opportunity, Rickey removed all the photographs on the walls except for the Lincoln portrait.
works.description: Historic photograph of Jackie Robinson signing his contract with Branch Rickey, with Lincoln portrait prominently displayed.
works.provenance: Branch Rickey estate, by descent to his grandson

works.title: Segregated Baseball Stadium
works.narrative: A photograph documenting the segregated seating arrangements at a baseball stadium, showing the physical manifestation of the color line in American sports venues.
works.description: Documentary photograph showing segregated seating at baseball stadium.
works.provenance: Civil rights photography archive

works.title: Indianapolis Indians Player
works.narrative: A portrait of a player from the Indianapolis Indians, representing the Negro League teams that provided opportunities for Black athletes during the segregation era.
works.description: Team portrait of Indianapolis Indians player in uniform.
works.provenance: Negro League historical collection

works.title: Brooklyn Dodgers Home Plate
works.narrative: Home plate at Ebbets Field, where Jackie Robinson made his Major League debut, breaking baseball's color barrier and changing American sports forever.
works.description: Photograph of home plate at Ebbets Field, site of Jackie Robinson's historic debut.
works.provenance: Brooklyn Historical Society

works.title: Color Line Integration Photograph 14
works.narrative: Historical photograph documenting aspects of racial integration in baseball, item 14 in the color line collection.
works.description: Documentary photograph related to the breaking of baseball's color barrier.
works.provenance: Various historical collections

works.title: Charles M. Conlon Baseball Photograph 1
works.narrative: Charles Martin Conlon was one of the most prolific and influential baseball photographers of the early 20th century. This photograph represents his distinctive style and technical mastery in capturing the essence of America's pastime.
works.description: Professional baseball photograph by Charles M. Conlon, known for his iconic images of early baseball stars and his technical innovation in sports photography.
works.provenance: Charles M. Conlon estate collection
works.exhibition: Featured in various baseball photography exhibitions including "The Golden Age of Baseball Photography" traveling exhibition.

works.title: Negro Leagues Baseball Photograph 1
works.narrative: The Negro Leagues represented one of the most important chapters in American baseball history, providing opportunities for Black athletes during the era of segregation. This photograph documents the skill, professionalism, and cultural significance of these leagues that operated parallel to Major League Baseball.
works.description: Historical photograph documenting Negro League baseball, showcasing the talent and organization of Black professional baseball during the segregation era.
works.provenance: Negro League historical archives and private collections
works.exhibition: Part of traveling exhibitions on Negro League history and African American sports heritage.

works.provenance: Various American sports photography collections and archives
works.exhibition: Featured in exhibitions celebrating American sports heritage and cultural history.
